Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Are there prenominal articles?
Are there postnominal articles?
What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
Example:
haksayng twu myeng
[student two person]
‘two students'

Feature: What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Detailed comment:
wa/kwa, mye/imye, hamye, lang/ilang, hako ‘and’
ha/wka, hako, lang/ilang ‘with’

Feature: Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?
Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?
Example:
i ‘this’
ku ‘that (close to hearer or known both to speaker and hearer)’
ce 'that over there'

Feature: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?
Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?
Example:
kilum-tul
oil-PL
‘different kinds of oil’

Feature: Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Example: Mia-ney ‘Mia's family’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?
Is there a noun class/gender system where sex is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?
Are there numeral classifiers?
Example: mali - animals, chay - houses, calwu - long slender objects

Feature: Are there possessive classifiers?
Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?
Example:
na uy yenphil
[1SG GEN pencil]
‘my pencil’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Example:
Milan.i nun ap-ass-ta ko hay-ss-ta
Milan TOP sick-PST-DC QT say-PST-DC
‘Milan said that she had been sick.'

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Are there morphological cases for oblique non-pronominal NPs (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there morphological cases for oblique independent personal pronouns (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there prepositions?
Are there postpositions?
Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Is there productive infixation in verbs?
Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?
Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions?
Can verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant?
Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Detailed comment: auxiliaries cwuta, tulita and ta(l)- are used instead, the main verb is in the infinitive

Feature: Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the monotransitive patient?
Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?
Example:
ape-nim un ka-ci an-h-usy-e
[father-HON TOP go-NOM NEG-do-HON.SBJ-INT]
‘Father is not going.’

Feature: Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?
Is there verb suppletion for participant number?
Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?
Are there conjugation classes?
Are there verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones?
Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?
Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?
Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?
Is there a copula for predicate nominals?
Are there serial verb constructions?
Can mood be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can tense be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Is verb compounding a regular process?
Example:
kep-nata
[fear-come.out]
‘be scared’
sal-ccita
[flesh-grow.fat]
‘gain weight’

Feature: Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?
Example: ssilum-hanta [wrestling-do] ‘[he] wrestles’

Feature: Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?
Is there an existential verb?
Example:
kyeysita ‘exist, stay (honorific)’
issta ‘stay, exist'

Feature: Are different posture verbs used obligatorily depending on an inanimate locatum's shape or position (e.g. 'to lie' vs. 'to stand')?
Is there a notably small number, i.e. about 100 or less, of verb roots in the language?
What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?
Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?
Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?
Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?
Comment: NEG is placed before the verb, SOV

Feature: Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?
Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?
Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?
Example:
ape-nim un ka-ci an-h-usy-e
[father-HON TOP go-NOM NEG-do-HON.SBJ-INT]
‘Father is not going.’
Minca nun sengkyek i coh-ci an-h-ta
[Minca TOP personality NOM good-NOM NEG-be-DELC]
'Minca's personality is not good.’

Feature: Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?
Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?
Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?
Is there a morphologically marked inverse on verbs?
Is there clause chaining?
Example:
tongsayng un pap ul an mek-ko hak.kyoey kas-sta
sister TOP meal ACC not eat-and school to go-PST-DC
'My sister did not eat her meal and went to school.'

Feature: Is there an overt verb marker dedicated to signalling coreference or noncoreference between the subject of one clause and an argument of an adjacent clause ("switch reference")?
Is there a morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses?
Are causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs?
Is there a causative construction involving an element that is unmistakably grammaticalized from a verb for 'to say'?
Example:
Kiho nun Nami ka ttena-ss-ta ko hay-ss-ta
[Kiho TOP Nami NOM leave-PST-DECL QUOT say-PST-DECL]
‘Kiho said that Nami had left.’
nay ka ku say lul/ka cquk-key hay-ss-ta
[1SG NOM the bird ACC/NOM die-so.that cause-PST-DECL]
‘I caused the bird to die.’

Feature: Are verbs reduplicated?
Are nouns reduplicated?
Example: cip-cip [house-house] ‘every house’

Feature: Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?
Example: swul-swul ‘smoothly’

Feature: Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?
Is there a logophoric pronoun?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can an article agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can the verb carry a marker of animacy of argument, unrelated to any gender/noun class of the argument visible in the NP domain?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in number?
Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?
Can an article agree with the noun in number?
Is there any productive diminutive marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Is there any productive augmentative marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Is there a gender system where a noun's phonological properties are a factor in class assignment?
What is the order of adnominal property word and noun?
Possible Values: multistate 1: ANM - N; 2: N - ANM; 3: both; 0: they cannot be used attributively

Feature: Is there a male/female distinction in 2nd person independent pronouns?
Is there a male/female distinction in 1st person independent pronouns?
Can an adnominal numeral agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
What is the order of the adnominal collective universal quantifier ('all') and the noun?
Example:
sakwa lul ta
[apple ACC all]
‘all apples’
cengchika-tul un motwu
[politician-PL TOP all]
‘all politicians’
uymwu-lul ta
[duty-PL all]
‘all duties’
haksayng-tul un motwu
[student-PL TOP all]
‘all students’

Feature: Do collective ('all') and distributive ('every') universal quantifiers differ in their forms or their syntactic positions?
Can predicative possession be expressed with a transitive 'habeo' verb?

Example:

[grandpa LOC book NOM many-POL]
‘Grandpa has many books.’
na eykey coh-un sayngkak i iss-e
[1SG at good-RLVZ idea NOM exist-INT]
‘I have a good idea.'

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a dative-coded possessor?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a possessor that is coded like an adnominal possessor?
Comment: The possessor is marked by a nominative case particle.
Example:
Mia ka cha ka iss-eyo
[Mia NOM car NOM exist-POL]
'Mia has a car.'

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessor and a possessum that is coded like a comitative argument?
Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?
Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?
Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?
Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?
Is there a comparative construction that includes a form that elsewhere means 'surpass, exceed'?
Is there a comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a locational meaning?
Can comparatives be expressed using two conjoined clauses?
Is there a comparative construction with a standard marker that elsewhere has neither a locational meaning nor a 'surpass/exceed' meaning?
Is there a bound comparative degree marker on the property word in a comparative construction?
Is there a non-bound comparative degree marker modifying the property word in a comparative construction?
Example:
pawktwu-san un hanla-san pota te nopha-ta
[Payktwu-Mt TOP Hanla-Mt than more high-DC]
‘Mt Paektu is higher than Mt Halla.’

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?
Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?

Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?
Can standard negation be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can standard negation be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Does the verb for 'give' have suppletive verb forms?
Is there an inclusory construction?
Is there a phonologically free passive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?
Is there a phonologically free antipassive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?
Can the agent be expressed overtly in a passive clause?
Is there a phonologically independent reflexive pronoun?
Is there a phonologically independent non-bipartite reciprocal pronoun?
Example: selo ‘each other, both sides’, phicha ‘each other, both sides’

Feature: Are there multiple past or multiple future tenses, distinguishing distance from Time of Reference?
Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to mood?
Are there special adnominal possessive pronouns that are not formed by an otherwise regular process?
Can augmentative meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Can diminutive meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?

Is dual number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is plural number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?

Is paucal number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is there a large class of nouns whose gender/noun class is not phonologically or semantically predictable?
Is there grammatical marking of direct evidence (perceived with the senses)?
Is there grammatical marking of indirect evidence (hearsay, inference, etc.)?
Is there an interrogative verb for content interrogatives (who?, what?, etc.)?
Is there a count/mass distinction in interrogative quantifiers?
Do (nominal) content interrogatives normally or frequently occur in situ?
Can the relative clause follow the noun?
Can the relative clause precede the noun?
Are there internally-headed relative clauses?
Are there correlative relative clauses?
Are there adjoined relative clauses?
Is there a decimal numeral system?
Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a quinary numeral system?
Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a vigesimal numeral system?
Is there a body-part tallying system?
Are all person categories neutralized in some voice, tense, aspect, mood and/or negation?
Is there a class of patient-labile verbs?
Does the verb for 'see' have suppletive verb forms?
Does the verb for 'come' have suppletive verb forms?
Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?
Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?
Comment: A marked by LOC (=OBL), P marked by NOM (=S/A)

Feature: Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?
Is there a politeness distinction in 2nd person forms?
Detailed comment: plain vs. familiar vs. intimate vs. blunt

Feature: Is there a preposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Is there a postposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Example:
Milan.i nun ap-ass-ta ko hay-ss-ta
Milan TOP sick-PST-DC QT say-PST-DC
‘Milan said that she had been sick.'

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessor?
Detailed comment: in his later work, ‘case particles’ are regarded as adpositions

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessed noun?
Detailed comment: in his later work, ‘case particles’ are regarded as adpositions

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessor?
Detailed comment: in his later work, ‘case particles’ are regarded as adpositions
Example:
na-uy yenphil
1-GEN pencil
'my pencil'

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessed noun?
Detailed comment: in his later work, ‘case particles’ are regarded as adpositions

Feature: Can mood be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can aspect be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can tense be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can the S or A argument be omitted from a pragmatically unmarked clause when the referent is inferrable from context ("pro-drop" or "null anaphora")?
Example:
halape-nim i kuli-sy-ess-eyo
[grandfather-HON NOM draw-SBJ.HON-PST-POL]
‘Did father draw [it]?’
kulay tangsin i cikcep kuli-sy-ess-e
[right self NOM in.person draw-SBJ.HON-PST-INT]
‘Yes, [he] drew [it] himself.'

Feature: Is root structure predominantly polysyllabic?
Are complex tonal distinctions lacking?
Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Example:
cwuk-essta [die-PST] ‘died’
nol-assta [play-PST] ‘played'

Feature: Is there tongue root vowel harmony?
Is there an initial velar nasal?
Is there an initial r-?
Are there initial consonant clusters in native words?
Is there a voicing distinction in stops?
Are borrowed verbs accommodated through a light-verb or a verbalizer?
Example:
puliphing-hanta [briefing-do] ‘[he] briefs’
khissu hayssta [kiss do] ‘kissed'

Feature: Are property words verbally or nominally encoded?
Is there partial emphatic reduplication of nominal property words?
Are morphemes connected linearly in a way that there is a one on one relationship between a morpheme and its meaning?
Is inflectional morphology predominantly suffixing?
Is there a mi-ti opposition in 1 vs. 2 SG personal pronouns?
Is the secondary oblique stem of personal pronouns formed with a dental nasal?
Are gerunds or adverbial participles used to mark adverbial subordination?
Are specific non-finite and finite suffixes expressed by a formally identical suffix?
Are specific negative verbs and negative suffixes/particles expressed by a formally identical suffix?
Example:
ape-nim un an ka-sy-e
[father-HON TOP NEG go-HON.SBJ-INT]
‘Father is not going.’
ape-nim un ka-ci an-h-usy-e
[father-HON TOP go-NOM NEG-do-HON.SBJ-INT]
‘Father is not going.'

Feature: Can 1PL marker be augmented by a collective plural marker?
Example: wuli-tul [we-PL] ‘we’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like nouns in predicative position?
Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as nouns?
Is there a non-initial velar nasal?
Example: kaŋaci ‘puppy’

Feature: Is there a reciprocal marker that is distinct from the reflexive marker?
Example:
ce(-casin), caki(-casin)
selo ‘each other, both sides’, phicha ‘each other, both sides’

Feature: Are there deranked purpose clauses?
Example:
Minca nun Waikiki ey swuyengha-le ka-ss-ta
[Minca TOP Waikiki LOC swim-PURP go-PST-DECL]
‘Minca went to Waikiki to swim.’

Feature: Can the notional subject of a want complement clause be left implicit when it is coreferential with the wanter?
Example:
hyeng un tampay lul/ka phiwu-ko siph-ess-eyo
[brother TOP cigarette ACC/NOM smoke-NOM wish-PST-POL]
‘My older brother wanted to smoke.’

Feature: Is there a voicing distinction in fricatives?
Are there two separate liquid phonemes (r/l)?
Is there vowel length distinction?
Example: coŋ ‘bell’ - co:ŋ ‘servant'

Feature: Are causative posture verbs derived and static-dynamic verbs basic?
Is there a male/female distinction in the sibling terms from the perspective of the speaker?
Example:
payk-pu ‘father’s older brother’
oy-swuk-mo ‘mother’s brother’
ko-swuk ‘father's sister’s husband’
i-mo-pu / i-swuk ‘mother’s sister’s husband’

Feature: Is there an age distinction in sibling terms?
Example:
hyeng ‘male’s older brother’
cey ‘male’s younger brother’

Feature: Are nouns most commonly derived from verbs than the other way around?
Detailed comment: not clear which strategy is more productive

Feature: Are ‘hand’ and ‘arm’ expressed by the same term?
Example:
son ‘hand’
phal ‘arm’

Feature: Are ‘moon’ and ‘month’ expressed by the same term?
Example:
tal ‘moon’
tal ‘month’

Feature: Is there a plural/collective suffix that is restricted to animates?
Can scalar additive operators (‘even’) also be used in non-scalar contexts (also)?
Is there a reflexive-possessive affix?
Are demonstratives verbally encoded?
Do cardinal numerals require agreement on noun phrases?
Example:
haksayng twu myeng
[student two person]
‘two students'

Feature: Is nominative case unmarked?
Detailed comment: there is no case marking whatsoever

Feature: Are accusative-marked objects specific while unmarked objects are non-specific?
Are recipient and location expressed by the same marker?
Detailed comment:
DAT: ey, eykey, hanthey
LOC: ey, eykey, hanthey, kkey, eyse, eykeyse, hantheyse

Feature: Is there a distinction between marking of interrogation in polar and content questions?
Detailed comment:
content: -ni and other speech level forms
polar: -ni and other speech level forms

Feature: Is acting agent in passive clause expressed by a dative-marked noun phrase?
Detailed comment: Locative and dative are marked identically.
Example:
totwuk i swunjkyeng eykey cap-hi-ess-ta
[thief NOM police LOC catch-PASS-PST-DECL]
‘The thief was caught by a policeman.’

Feature: Is the subject of an adnominalized clause marked by the genitive case?
Can a passive construction have adversative meaning?
Detailed comment: with verbs palp-hita 'be stepped on’, ppayas-kita, cap-kita ‘be caught’, mul-lita 'be bitten', kkocip-hita 'be pinched', cha-ita 'be kicked’, cal-lita 'be cut’

Feature: Can demonstrative/interrogative verbs be derived from pronouns and light verbs ‘to do’?
Are causative and passive expressed by a formally identical marker?
Example:
po-i-ta
[see-CAUS/PASS-DECL]
‘be seen; show’

Feature: Are converb suffixes and deverbal noun suffixes formally identical?
Are quotative markers adverbial derivations from a verb ‘to say’?
Can relational adpositions (e.g. ‘under’) be derived from a place noun (e.g. ‘bottom’) and a locational suffix (e.g. at LOC)?
Example:
kkaci ‘till, as far as' - s kac(ang) ‘the edge of'
kkey 'around time' - ke kuy 'that place'

Feature: Are hortatives/purposives encoded by the same marker (eventually involving a converb of the verb ‘to say’)?
Are denominal verbalizers and deverbal suffixes sharing comparable actional semantics expressed by the same marker?
Is ‘it is becoming if’ grammaticalized in deontic modality?
Example:
ne nun ka-to coh-ta
[2SG TOP go-though good-DELC]
'You may go; It is okay with you even if you go.'

Feature: Is imperative form for 2SG identical to bare verb root?
Example:
mek-ela
[eat-IMP]
‘Please eat.’

Feature: Is person marking on the verb formally identical to independent personal pronouns?
Detailed comment: there is person marking on the verb whatsoever

Feature: Is there a comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a meaning ‘to see’?
Example:
Milani pota Mia nun te yeyppu-ta
[Milan than Mia TOP more pretty-DECL]
‘Mia is more pretty than Milan.’
tuli-e-ta [put in-INF-and see] ‘look into'

Feature: Can a copula be derived from original posture verbs?
Can the notional subject of a want complement clause be expressed overtly when it is coreferential with the wanter?
Are ‘foot’ and ‘leg’ expressed by the same term?
Example:
pal ‘foot'
tali ‘leg’

Feature: Are there balanced purpose clauses?
Is there an adposition or a particle formally similar to the verb?
Example:
ha-ko [say-and] - hako/ko QUOT
po-ko [see-and] - poko DAT
kaci-ko [hold-and] - kaciko INST
puth-e [stick.to-and] - puthe ABL
coch-a [follow-and] - cocha ‘even’
kyesi-e [stay-and] - kkeyse HON

Feature: Is completive aspect expressed by a marker formally identical to the verb ’to put/throw away’?
Detailed comment:
mek-e peli-ess-eyo
[eat-INF throw-PST-DECL:POL]
‘I have eaten them up.’

Feature: Are there adpositions to mark core NPs?
Are there adpositions to mark oblique NPs?
Are there three laryngeal contrasts for stops?
Can numeral precede the noun?
Can numeral follow the noun?
Can demonstrative precede the noun?
Example:

[that friend-PL]

Feature: Can demonstrative follow the noun?
Can adnominal possessor precede the possessed noun?
Example:

[1SG GEN pencil]
‘my pencil’

Feature: Can adnominal possessor follow the possessed noun?
Can adnominal property word precede the noun?
Can adnominal property word follow the noun?

Can adnominal collective universal quantifier (‘all’) follow the noun?

Feature: Is there height vowel harmony?
Is there labial vowel harmony?
Is there an initial l-?
Do numerals have the same form in attributive and predicative use?
Is the meaning ‘to hunt’ expressed as noun+denominalizer?
Are instrumental and comitative expressed by the same marker?
Are the meanings ‘to see’ and ‘to try’ expressed by formally identical verbs?
What is the order of personal possessive suffixes and case suffixes?
Possible Values: 0: one category missing; 1: POSS-case; 2: case-POSS; 3: both

Feature: Is the pragmatically unmarked order of SV in intransitive clauses?
Is the pragmatically unmarked order of VS in intransitive clauses?
Is there an aspiration distinction in stops?
